events.title: Author Addresses Public Uproar and Defends Introductory Sketch
detailed_summary: The author expresses a mix of surprise and amusement at the significant commotion his introductory sketch to "The Scarlet Letter," which depicted official life, has caused within his local community.

He ironically observes that the community's reaction was so intense it was comparable to him having committed a destructive act against the Custom-House and gravely harmed a specific, respected elderly individual, whom he is falsely accused of targeting with malice.
He asserts that genuine public disapproval, if he believed it was justified, would weigh heavily on him.

In response to the outcry, he meticulously reviewed the introductory pages, with the full intention of modifying or removing any offensive material and offering the best possible amends for the perceived transgressions.

Upon this review, he concludes that the sketch's most defining characteristics are its candid and good-hearted humor, along with the general accuracy of his sincere depictions of the characters therein.
He explicitly refutes any accusations of harboring animosity or ill-will, whether personal or political, as the motivation behind writing the sketch.

He admits the sketch could have been omitted entirely without any loss to the public or detriment to the book itself, but having chosen to write it, he is confident it was executed in the kindest possible spirit and, to the best of his abilities, with a vivid and truthful portrayal.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: MUCH to the author’s surprise, and (if he may say so without additional offence) considerably to his amusement, he finds that his sketch of official life, introductory to The Scarlet Letter, has created an unprecedented excitement in the respectable community immediately around him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The sketch might, perhaps, have been wholly omitted, without loss to the public, or detriment to the book; but, having undertaken to write it, he conceives that it could not have been done in a better or a kindlier spirit, nor, so far as his abilities availed, with a livelier effect of truth.

events.text_segment: MUCH to the author’s surprise, and (if he may say so without additional offence) considerably to his amusement, he finds that his sketch of official life, introductory to The Scarlet Letter, has created an unprecedented excitement in the respectable community immediately around him. It could hardly have been more violent, indeed, had he burned down the Custom-House, and quenched its last smoking ember in the blood of a certain venerable personage, against whom he is supposed to cherish a peculiar malevolence. As the public disapprobation would weigh very heavily on him, were he conscious of deserving it, the author begs leave to say, that he has carefully read over the introductory pages, with a purpose to alter or expunge whatever might be found amiss, and to make the best reparation in his power for the atrocities of which he has been adjudged guilty. But it appears to him, that the only remarkable features of the sketch are its frank and genuine good-humor, and the general accuracy with which he has conveyed his sincere impressions of the characters therein described. As to enmity, or ill-feeling of any kind, personal or political, he utterly disclaims such motives. The sketch might, perhaps, have been wholly omitted, without loss to the public, or detriment to the book; but, having undertaken to write it, he conceives that it could not have been done in a better or a kindlier spirit, nor, so far as his abilities availed, with a livelier effect of truth.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
PREFACE TO THE SECOND EDITION.

MUCH to the author’s surprise, and (if he may say so without additional offence) considerably to his amusement, he finds that his sketch of official life, introductory to The Scarlet Letter, has created an unprecedented excitement in the respectable community immediately around him. It could hardly have been more violent, indeed, if he had burned down the Custom-House, and smoked a pipe amid the ruins, or scoured with his great toe, instead of a pen, the unfortunate Governor’s scarlet robe. And this excitement has nevertheless caused no slight trouble to the author, by bringing upon him the whole weight of respectable indignation, in consequence of some innocent passages, alluding to a certain venerable personage, who continues to hold an office in the Custom-House. Until a recent period, an officer of that institution for forty years back, he has recently been made Collector of the Port; inasmuch as there was no longer the physical ability to discharge the active duties of his former station. There is said to be a gentleman alive, of this name, and in this office; and the author has been censured, not only for his irreverent levity, and utter want of filial reverence, in this fantastic sketch of a gentleman in years, but for his deliberate malignity, allowing himself to expose to the public eye, with malice aforethought, the infirmities of a most respectable person. 

Now, if there be a gentleman alive, that has good reason to feel aggrieved by any thing in the foregoing pages, it is certainly the person indicated as the Inspector of the Custom-House. He acknowledges to have incurred a debt of deep gratitude to this gentleman, and to owe more than he can ever expect to pay, for the kindness and assistance received at his hands, and for the forbearance, only not boundless, that he has constantly experienced. He feels it impossible to look in the face of this dear and honored friend, and not to know that there are ten chances to one, of his dying in the attempt, if he were to do him conscious wrong; and he cannot conceive of any evil that he would not sooner perpetrate, than to wound, by a word or a look, that venerable spirit. 

What, then, is the matter? The author has been told, in one form and another, that he has committed a great wrong; that he has been guilty of a most irreverent attack upon the sanctity of the grave; and that, in short, he has committed the unpardonable sin. He has been told, moreover, that he has done great wrong to the living, by wantonly and cruelly exposing to the public eye the infirmities of a most respectable person. 

He has been told, in short, that he has committed a great wrong.

events.title: Author's Resolute Decision to Republish Sketch Unchanged
detailed_summary: Consequently, based on his unchanged assessment of the sketch, the author declares he feels compelled to republish his introductory piece exactly as it was originally written, without making any alterations or excisions.
The author's statement and decision are formally concluded with the indication of place and date: Salem, March 30, 1850.

events.title: Author's Preface: Justification for Autobiographical Writing
detailed_summary: The narrator acknowledges his recurring impulse towards autobiographical writing, despite a general disinclination to discuss personal matters.
He compares this act to a previous autobiographical piece about the Old Manse and likens himself to the 'famous P. P., Clerk of this Parish'.
He posits that authors often write not for a wide audience, but for a select few who can truly understand them, sometimes seeking a perfect sympathetic connection.

The narrator discusses the fine line an author must walk in self-revelation, suggesting it's permissible to share surrounding circumstances and some personal aspects while keeping the 'inmost Me' veiled, as if speaking to a kind, understanding friend.
He justifies the current Custom-House sketch by explaining its necessity in contextualizing the subsequent narrative ('The Scarlet Letter') and authenticating its origins.
His primary stated reason for this personal address is to establish his role as merely an editor, or slightly more, of the main tale.
He adds that this preface also allows him to offer a glimpse into a unique way of life and its characters, including himself.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It is a little remarkable, that—though disinclined to talk overmuch of myself and my affairs at the fireside, and to my personal friends—an autobiographical impulse should twice in my life have taken possession of me, in addressing the public.

events.text_segment:
T is a little remarkable, that—though disinclined to talk overmuch of myself and my affairs at the fireside, and to my personal friends—an autobiographical impulse should twice in my life have taken possession of me, in addressing the public. The first time was three or four years since, when I favored the reader—inexcusably, and for no earthly reason, that either the indulgent reader or the intrusive author could imagine—with a description of my way of life in the deep quietude of an Old Manse. And now—because, beyond my deserts, I was happy enough to find a listener or two on the former occasion—I again seize the public by the button, and talk of my three years’ experience in a Custom-House. The example of the famous “P. P., Clerk of this Parish,” was never more faithfully followed. The truth seems to be, however, that, when he casts his leaves forth upon the wind, the author addresses, not the many who will fling aside his volume, or never take it up, but the few who will understand him, better than most of his schoolmates or lifemates. Some authors, indeed, do far more than this, and indulge themselves in such confidential depths of revelation as could fittingly be addressed, only and exclusively, to the one heart and mind of perfect sympathy; as if the printed book, thrown at large on the wide world, were certain to find out the divided segment of the writer’s own nature, and complete his circle of existence by bringing him into communion with it. It is scarcely decorous, however, to speak all, even where we speak impersonally. But, as thoughts are frozen and utterance benumbed, unless the speaker stand in some true relation with his audience, it may be pardonable to imagine that a friend, a kind and apprehensive, though not the closest friend, is listening to our talk; and then, a native reserve being thawed by this genial consciousness, we may prate of the circumstances that lie around us, and even of ourself, but still keep the inmost Me behind its veil. To this extent, and within these limits, an author, methinks, may be autobiographical, without violating either the reader’s rights or his own.
It will be seen, likewise, that this Custom-House sketch has a certain propriety, of a kind always recognized in literature, as explaining how a large portion of the following pages came into my possession, and as offering proofs of the authenticity of a narrative therein contained. This, in fact,—a desire to put myself in my true position as editor, or very little more, of the most prolix among the tales that make up my volume,—this, and no other, is my true reason for assuming a personal relation with the public. In accomplishing the main purpose, it has appeared allowable, by a few extra touches, to give a faint representation of a mode of life not heretofore described, together with some of the characters that move in it, among whom the author happened to make one.

events.title: The Decaying Salem Custom-House and its Symbolic Eagle
detailed_summary: The narrator describes the setting of the Custom-House in his native Salem, located at the head of a once-bustling but now decayed wharf.
The wharf is depicted with dilapidated warehouses, minimal commercial activity, and signs of long neglect like unthrifty grass.
The Custom-House itself is a spacious brick building, flying the republic's banner in a manner indicating a civil, not military, post.
Its entrance features a portico, granite steps, and a prominent American eagle emblem.
The eagle is described with fierce, truculent features, appearing to threaten the community and warn against intrusion.
Despite its menacing look, many people seek refuge under the federal eagle's wing, perhaps mistakenly believing it to be tender.
The narrator comments that the eagle, in reality, lacks tenderness and is prone to harshly casting off those it shelters.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In my native town of Salem, at the head of what, half a century ago, in the days of old King Derby, was a bustling wharf,—but which is now burdened with decayed wooden warehouses, and exhibits few or no symptoms of commercial life; except, perhaps, a bark or brig, half-way down its melancholy length, discharging hides; or, nearer at hand, a Nova Scotia schooner, pitching out her cargo of firewood,—at the head, I say, of this dilapidated wharf, which the tide often overflows, and along which, at the base and in the rear of the row of buildings, the track of many languid years is seen in a border of unthrifty grass,—here, with a view from its front windows adown this not very enlivening prospect, and thence across the harbor, stands a spacious edifice of brick.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But she has no great tenderness, even in her best of moods, and, sooner or later,—oftener soon than late,—is apt to fling off her nestlings, with a scratch of her claw, a dab of her beak, or a rankling wound from her barbed arrows.

events.text_segment: In my native town of Salem, at the head of what, half a century ago, in the days of old King Derby, was a bustling wharf,—but which is now burdened with decayed wooden warehouses, and exhibits few or no symptoms of commercial life; except, perhaps, a bark or brig, half-way down its melancholy length, discharging hides; or, nearer at hand, a Nova Scotia schooner, pitching out her cargo of firewood,—at the head, I say, of this dilapidated wharf, which the tide often overflows, and along which, at the base and in the rear of the row of buildings, the track of many languid years is seen in a border of unthrifty grass,—here, with a view from its front windows adown this not very enlivening prospect, and thence across the harbor, stands a spacious edifice of brick. From the loftiest point of its roof, during precisely three and a half hours of each forenoon, floats or droops, in breeze or calm, the banner of the republic; but with the thirteen stripes turned vertically, instead of horizontally, and thus indicating that a civil, and not a military post of Uncle Sam’s government is here established. Its front is ornamented with a portico of half a dozen wooden pillars, supporting a balcony, beneath which a flight of wide granite steps descends towards the street. Over the entrance hovers an enormous specimen of the American eagle, with outspread wings, a shield before her breast, and, if I recollect aright, a bunch of intermingled thunderbolts and barbed arrows in each claw. With the customary infirmity of temper that characterizes this unhappy fowl, she appears, by the fierceness of her beak and eye, and the general truculency of her attitude, to threaten mischief to the inoffensive community; and especially to warn all citizens, careful of their safety, against intruding on the premises which she overshadows with her wings. Nevertheless, vixenly as she looks, many people are seeking, at this very moment, to shelter themselves under the wing of the federal eagle; imagining, I presume, that her bosom has all the softness and snugness of an eider-down pillow. But she has no great tenderness, even in her best of moods, and, sooner or later,—oftener soon than late,—is apt to fling off her nestlings, with a scratch of her claw, a dab of her beak, or a rankling wound from her barbed arrows.

detailed_summary: The narrator observes that grass growing in the pavement cracks around the Custom-House indicates infrequent business.
He describes occasional mornings of heightened activity, reminiscent of Salem's more prosperous past before trade shifted to New York or Boston.

events.text_segment:
The pavement round about the above-described edifice—which we may as well name at once as the Custom-House of the port—has grass enough growing in its chinks to show that it has not, of late days, been worn by any multitudinous resort of business. In some months of the year, however, there often chances a forenoon when affairs move onward with a livelier tread. Such occasions might remind the elderly citizen of that period before the last war with England, when Salem was a port by itself; not scorned, as she is now, by her own merchants and ship-owners, who permit her wharves to crumble to ruin, while their ventures go to swell, needlessly and imperceptibly, the mighty flood of commerce at New York or Boston. On some such morning, when three or four vessels happen to have arrived at once,—usually from Africa or South America,—or to be on the verge of their departure thitherward, there is a sound of frequent feet, passing briskly up and down the granite steps. Here, before his own wife has greeted him, you may greet the sea-flushed shipmaster, just in port, with his vessel’s papers under his arm, in a tarnished tin box. Here, too, comes his owner, cheerful or sombre, gracious or in the sulks, accordingly as his scheme of the now accomplished voyage has been realized in merchandise that will readily be turned to gold, or has buried him under a bulk of incommodities, such as nobody will care to rid him of. Here, likewise,—the germ of the wrinkle-browed, grizzly-bearded, care-worn merchant,—we have the smart young clerk, who gets the taste of traffic as a wolf-cub does of blood, and already sends adventures in his master’s ships, when he had better be sailing mimic-boats upon a mill-pond. Another figure in the scene is the outward-bound sailor in quest of a protection; or the recently arrived one, pale and feeble, seeking a passport to the hospital. Nor must we forget the captains of the rusty little schooners that bring firewood from the British provinces; a rough-looking set of tarpaulins, without the alertness of the Yankee aspect, but contributing an item of no slight importance to our decaying trade.
Cluster all these individuals together, as they sometimes were, with other miscellaneous ones to diversify the group, and, for the time being, it made the Custom-House a stirring scene. More frequently, however, on ascending the steps, you would discern—in the entry, if it were summer time, or in their appropriate rooms, if wintry or inclement weather—a row of venerable figures, sitting in old-fashioned chairs, which were tipped on their hind legs back against the wall. Oftentimes they were asleep, but occasionally might be heard talking together, in voices between speech and a snore, and with that lack of energy that distinguishes the occupants of almshouses, and all other human beings who depend for subsistence on charity, on monopolized labor, or anything else, but their own independent exertions. These old gentlemen—seated, like Matthew, at the receipt of customs, but not very liable to be summoned thence, like him, for apostolic errands—were Custom-House officers.

In some months of the year, however, there occur brief intervals, of two or three successive days, when those who live in the vicinity are startled by the unwonted throng, and bustle, and, as it were, tidal murmur, that flows and eddies about the entrance of the Custom-House. Then, you may discern all the chief figures of that microcosm of human business, punctually on their affairs, and in various degrees of haste or delay. Here, immediately at the entrance, you perceive the sea-flushed shipmaster, his face all alive with the winds and salt spray of the ocean, his voice husky with shouting to his mates on deck, and his stride still लंबा and rolling, even on the firm ground. He has come to report the arrival of his vessel, and to make due entry at the Custom-House. Yonder, in a corner of the vestibule, you see the ship-owner, a man of consequence, with a countenance of deep solicitude, or of brisk and joyous alacrity, according as his voyage has proved a failure or a success. A little further within, you find the smart young clerk, who has come hither to transact some business for his employer, and who is in a terrible hurry to get it done. And, in a third corner, you behold the outward-bound sailor, seeking a passage to the hospital, or to the next port, or to the world's end, whichever he can get soonest. Or, perhaps, you see a recently arrived sailor, just come ashore, with a bundle under his arm, and a look of bewilderment in his face, as if he were not quite sure whether he were in Salem or in some foreign land. And, in the midst of all this, you may catch a glimpse of the rough-looking captains of firewood schooners, who have come to make their entries, and who are as much at home in the Custom-House as they are on their own decks.

```python
But these are rare and fleeting scenes, which occur only when a vessel arrives or departs. More commonly, you would find the interior of the Custom-House occupied by a set of elderly gentlemen, who are the permanent officials of the establishment. They are, for the most part, men of advanced age, with a decided tendency to corpulence, and a general air of having nothing to do. You will find them, perhaps, asleep in their chairs, tilted back against the wall, or conversing in a low, monotonous tone, with a distinct lack of energy or animation. They seem to have been born in the Custom-House, and to have lived there ever since, with no other purpose than to draw their salaries and to wait for the hour of their dismissal. They are like the inhabitants of almshouses, dependent on means other than their own efforts, and are as unlikely to be called to 'apostolic errands' as the most confirmed idler in the land.
"""
```

events.title: The Narrator's Former Office and Political Dismissal
characters: The Author (Narrator, as the Locofoco Surveyor)
detailed_summary: A specific office room within the Custom-House is described: about fifteen feet square, lofty, with arched windows offering views of the wharf and Derby Street, and glimpses of nearby shops and loitering old sailors.
The room itself is cobwebbed, dingy, with a sand-strewn floor, suggesting infrequent cleaning by women.
Its sparse furniture includes a stove, an old pine desk with a three-legged stool, decrepit wooden chairs, and a small library of official volumes.
A tin pipe serves for vocal communication with other parts of the building.
The narrator reveals that he, the 'Locofoco Surveyor,' occupied this office some six months prior, often seen pacing or reading the newspaper.
He states that he is no longer there, having been dismissed by the 'besom of reform,' with a 'worthier successor' now in his place.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Furthermore, on the left hand as you enter the front door, is a certain room or office, about fifteen feet square, and of a lofty height; with two of its arched windows commanding a view of the aforesaid dilapidated wharf, and the third looking across a narrow lane, and along a portion of Derby Street.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The besom of reform has swept him out of office; and a worthier successor wears his dignity, and pockets his emoluments.

events.text_segment: Furthermore, on the left hand as you enter the front door, is a certain room or office, about fifteen feet square, and of a lofty height; with two of its arched windows commanding a view of the aforesaid dilapidated wharf, and the third looking across a narrow lane, and along a portion of Derby Street. All three give glimpses of the shops of grocers, block-makers, slop-sellers, and ship-chandlers; around the doors of which are generally to be seen, laughing and gossiping, clusters of old salts, and such other wharf-rats as haunt the Wapping of a seaport. The room itself is cobwebbed, and dingy with old paint; its floor is strewn with gray sand, in a fashion that has elsewhere fallen into long disuse; and it is easy to conclude, from the general slovenliness of the place, that this is a sanctuary into which womankind, with her tools of magic, the broom and mop, has very infrequent access. In the way of furniture, there is a stove with a voluminous funnel; an old pine desk, with a three-legged stool beside it; two or three wooden-bottom chairs, exceedingly decrepit and infirm; and—not to forget the library—on some shelves, a score or two of volumes of the Acts of Congress, and a bulky Digest of the Revenue Laws. A tin pipe ascends through the ceiling, and forms a medium of vocal communication with other parts of the edifice. And here, some six months ago,—pacing from corner to corner, or lounging on the long-legged stool, with his elbow on the desk, and his eyes wandering up and down the columns of the morning newspaper,—you might have recognized, honored reader, the same individual who welcomed you into his cheery little study, where the sunshine glimmered so pleasantly through the willow branches, on the western side of the Old Manse. But now, should you go thither to seek him, you would inquire in vain for the Locofoco Surveyor. The besom of reform has swept him out of office; and a worthier successor wears his dignity, and pockets his emoluments.

An old gentleman in a reefer coat occupies the room just within the entrance, and is so called, I suppose, to distinguish him from his juniors and inferiors; who will be apt to speak of him, however, with that irreverence which is perhaps the sole privilege of an American citizen. In this little world into which I had stepped, these old gentlemen—all fallen into this comfortable decadence, were the chief inhabitants, as they had long been before I came, and as they will probably be long after I have departed. They were provided with comfortable easy-chairs, and had each a stove for the winter time, and as it is a matter of public record, I may as well state, that the fire was kept alive from morning till night, and was a most hospitable and genial fire, and that the old gentlemen sat around it, and smoked their pipes, and told their stories, and were as comfortable and as happy as they could be. The room itself, however, was cobwebbed, and dingy, and dismal, and the floor was strewn with sand, as if it were a public house, and had not been swept for a week. The furniture consisted of an old pine desk, with a three-legged stool beside it, and a few decrepit wooden chairs, and a small library of official volumes, and a tin pipe, which served for vocal communication with other parts of the building. This was the apartment occupied, some six months since, by the Locofoco Surveyor. In the open air, and on the wharf, I used to see him, at all hours of the day, pacing to and fro, or leaning against a post, or reading the newspaper. He is no longer there. A worthier successor, I trust, occupies his place. The besom of reform has swept him out of office, and a worthier successor, I trust, occupies his place.

events.title: Salem's Hold: Ancestral Roots and Puritan Legacy
characters: His Puritan Ancestors (the original Briton, his son)
detailed_summary: The narrator confesses a deep, almost unrealized affection for his native Salem, despite its physically uninspiring and tame appearance, which he likens to a disarranged checker-board.
He attributes this sentiment to the profound and ancient roots his family has in the town's soil, dating back nearly two and a quarter centuries to the first Puritan emigrant of his name.
This connection is described as a 'sensuous sympathy of dust for dust,' a bond few of his transplanted countrymen might understand.
The feeling also has a moral quality, linked to the haunting figure of his first ancestor, a man of dim grandeur, both a leader and a persecutor, notably of Quakers.
His ancestor's son inherited this persecuting spirit, becoming infamous during the witch trials, leaving a 'stain' on his name.
The narrator formally takes shame upon himself for his ancestors' cruelties and prays for the removal of any resulting curse on his family line.
He humorously imagines his Puritan forefathers scorning his profession as a writer of story-books, deeming it an idle and degenerate pursuit.
Despite this imagined disdain, he acknowledges that strong traits of their nature are intertwined with his own.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: This old town of Salem—my native place, though I have dwelt much away from it, both in boyhood and maturer years—possesses, or did possess, a hold on my affections, the force of which I have never realized during my seasons of actual residence here.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And yet, let them scorn me as they will, strong traits of their nature have intertwined themselves with mine.

events.text_segment:
This old town of Salem—my native place, though I have dwelt much away from it, both in boyhood and maturer years—possesses, or did possess, a hold on my affections, the force of which I have never realized during my seasons of actual residence here. Indeed, so far as its physical aspect is concerned, with its flat, unvaried surface, covered chiefly with wooden houses, few or none of which pretend to architectural beauty,—its irregularity, which is neither picturesque nor quaint, but only tame,—its long and lazy street, lounging wearisomely through the whole extent of the peninsula, with Gallows Hill and New Guinea at one end, and a view of the almshouse at the other,—such being the features of my native town, it would be quite as reasonable to form a sentimental attachment to a disarranged checker-board. And yet, though invariably happiest elsewhere, there is within me a feeling for old Salem, which, in lack of a better phrase, I must be content to call affection. The sentiment is probably assignable to the deep and aged roots which my family has struck into the soil. It is now nearly two centuries and a quarter since the original Briton, the earliest emigrant of my name, made his appearance in the wild and forest-bordered settlement, which has since become a city. And here his descendants have been born and died, and have mingled their earthy substance with the soil; until no small portion of it must necessarily be akin to the mortal frame wherewith, for a little while, I walk the streets. In part, therefore, the attachment which I speak of is the mere sensuous sympathy of dust for dust. Few of my countrymen can know what it is; nor, as frequent transplantation is perhaps better for the stock, need they consider it desirable to know.
But the sentiment has likewise its moral quality. The figure of that first ancestor, invested by family tradition with a dim and dusky grandeur, was present to my boyish imagination, as far back as I can remember. It still haunts me, and induces a sort of home-feeling with the past, which I scarcely claim in reference to the present phase of the town. I seem to have a stronger claim to a residence here on account of this grave, bearded, sable-cloaked and steeple-crowned progenitor,—who came so early, with his Bible and his sword, and trode the unworn street with such a stately port, and made so large a figure, as a man of war and peace,—a stronger claim than for myself, whose name is seldom heard and my face hardly known. He was a soldier, legislator, judge; he was a ruler in the Church; he had all the Puritanic traits, both good and evil. He was likewise a bitter persecutor, as witness the Quakers, who have remembered him in their histories, and relate an incident of his hard severity towards a woman of their sect, which will last longer, it is to be feared, than any record of his better deeds, although these were many. His son, too, inherited the persecuting spirit, and made himself so conspicuous in the martyrdom of the witches, that their blood may fairly be said to have left a stain upon him. So deep a stain, indeed, that his old dry bones, in the Charter Street burial-ground, must still retain it, if they have not crumbled utterly to dust! I know not whether these ancestors of mine bethought themselves to repent, and ask pardon of Heaven for their cruelties; or whether they are now groaning under the heavy consequences of them, in another state of being. At all events, I, the present writer, as their representative, hereby take shame upon myself for their sakes, and pray that any curse incurred by them—as I have heard, and as the dreary and unprosperous condition of the race, for many a long year back, would argue to exist—may be now and henceforth removed.
Doubtless, however, either of these stern and black-browed Puritans would have thought it quite a sufficient retribution for his sins, that, after so long a lapse of years, the old trunk of the family tree, with so much venerable moss upon it, should have borne, as its topmost bough, an idler like myself. No aim, that I have ever cherished, would they recognize as laudable; no success of mine—if my life, beyond its domestic scope, had ever been brightened by success—would they deem otherwise than worthless, if not positively disgraceful. “What is he?” murmurs one gray shadow of my forefathers to the other. “A writer of story-books! What kind of a business in life—what mode of glorifying God, or being serviceable to mankind in his day and generation—may that be? Why, the degenerate fellow might as well have been a fiddler!” Such are the compliments bandied between my great-grandsires and myself, across the gulf of time! And yet, let them scorn me as they will, strong traits of their nature have intertwined themselves with mine.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: This old town of Salem—my native place, though I have dwelt much away from it, both in boyhood and maturer years—possesses, or did possess, a hold on my affections, the force of which I have never realized during my seasons of actual residence here. There is a fatality, a feeling so irresistible and inevitable that it has the force of doom, which impels me to seek my home in a place where my forefathers have been so long rooted, and where my earthly existence has commenced. I have halted upon the threshold of my native town, and have longed to enter, but have dreaded it. Within a little time, however, I was once more upon the pavement of its streets, and beneath the shadow of its sable roofs. I knew well that I was not destined to remain there; and yet, so strong was the sense of a system that had been destroyed, that I could not resist the impulse to connect myself with the like system. My affection for the old town of Salem is not a matter of taste; the long connection of a family with one spot, as its birthplace and burial-place, creates an intimacy of relationship between the human organism and the soil, which is almost independent of the character of the scene. Our bodies are moulded of its dust, and grow down into it, a part of the soil itself, or rather, a part of the inhabitants of the soil. We mingle our earthly substance with the earth; and, therefore, our hearts are knit to it with a sort of sensuous sympathy, which is incomprehensible to those who have no such inheritance. But, besides this physical tie, there is a moral one, the influence of which is not to be described. I am a descendant of men who were among the first settlers of the town, and whose names are on the records of the earliest history of the place. I have a dim and imperfect recollection of the first emigrant of my name, who came over with the Puritans, and was one of the founders of the colony. He was a man of rank, with a stern and wrinkled countenance, a leader in the councils of the infant settlement, and a persecutor of the Quakers. His son inherited the persecuting spirit, and was one of the most active in the witchcraft delusion. He was a judge in the witch trials, and was one of those who signed the death-warrants. He was a man of iron, with a heart of stone. He died in the odor of sanctity, as a man who had done God service. I, the descendant, take shame upon myself for their cruelties, and pray that God will not visit the sins of the fathers upon the children. I have no great faith in the efficacy of this prayer, but I offer it up, nevertheless. I have a sort of hereditary taste for the old town, and for its inhabitants. I like to walk about the streets, and to see the old houses, and to think of the men and women who have lived in them. I like to see the descendants of the old families, and to trace the resemblance between them and their ancestors. I like to see the children playing in the streets, and to think that they are the children of the same race that has inhabited the town for so many generations. I like to see the ships in the harbor, and to think of the commerce that has been carried on from this port for so many years. simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: This old town of Salem—my native place, though I have dwelt much away from it, both in boyhood and maturer years—possesses, or did possess, a hold on my affections, the force of which I have never realized during my seasons of actual residence here. There is a fatality, a feeling so irresistible and inevitable that it has the force of doom, which impels me to seek my home in a place where my forefathers have been so long rooted, and where my earthly existence has commenced. I have halted upon the threshold of my native town, and have longed to enter, but have dreaded it. Within a little time, however, I was once more upon the pavement of its streets, and beneath the shadow of its sable roofs. I knew well that I was not destined to remain there; and yet, so strong was the sense of a system that had been destroyed, that I could not resist the impulse to connect myself with the like system. My affection for the old town of Salem is not a matter of taste; the long connection of a family with one spot, as its birthplace and burial-place, creates an intimacy of relationship between the human organism and the soil, which is almost independent of the character of the scene. Our bodies are moulded of its dust, and grow down into it, a part of the soil itself, or rather, a part of the inhabitants of the soil. We mingle our earthly substance with the earth; and, therefore, our hearts are knit to it with a sort of sensuous sympathy, which is incomprehensible to those who have no such inheritance. But, besides this physical tie, there is a moral one, the influence of which is not to be described. I am a descendant of men who were among the first settlers of the town, and whose names are on the records of the earliest history of the place. I have a dim and imperfect recollection of the first emigrant of my name, who came over with the Puritans, and was one of the founders of the colony. He was a man of rank, with a stern and wrinkled countenance, a leader in the councils of the infant settlement, and a persecutor of the Quakers. His son inherited the persecuting spirit, and was one of the most active in the witchcraft delusion. He was a judge in the witch trials, and was one of those who signed the death-warrants. He was a man of iron, with a heart of stone. He died in the odor of sanctity, as a man who had done God service. I, the descendant, take shame upon myself for their cruelties, and pray that God will not visit the sins of the fathers upon the children. I have no great faith in the efficacy of this prayer, but I offer it up, nevertheless. I have a sort of hereditary taste for the old town, and for its inhabitants. I like to walk about the streets, and to see the old houses, and to think of the men and women who have lived in them. I like to see the descendants of the old families, and to trace the resemblance between them and their ancestors. I like to see the ships in the harbor, and to think of the commerce that has been carried on from this port for so many years. events.title: Generational Stagnation and the Need for New Roots
detailed_summary: The narrator reflects on his family line, noting that after the initial two energetic Puritan generations, subsequent ancestors maintained respectability but performed no memorable public deeds, gradually fading from prominence.
For over a century, his family members were seafarers, each generation passing from ship boy to shipmaster before retiring, reinforcing a deep connection to Salem as their place of birth and burial.
This long familial connection to a single place is described as an instinctual, 'oyster-like tenacity,' independent of the location's actual charms.
He acknowledges that Salem holds no particular joy for him, citing its dull houses, mud, chill wind, and cold social atmosphere, yet the 'spell' of natal attachment remains powerful.
He felt it was almost his destiny to make Salem his home, continuing the visible representation of his lineage in the town.
However, he now views this deep-rooted sentiment as evidence of an unhealthy connection that must be severed.
He compares human nature to a potato, arguing it cannot flourish if replanted in the same worn-out soil for too many generations.
Consequently, he has ensured his children have different birthplaces and will encourage them to establish roots in new, unaccustomed earth.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: My children have had other birthplaces, and, so far as their fortunes may be within my control, shall strike their roots into unaccustomed earth.

events.text_segment: Planted deep, in the town’s earliest infancy and childhood, by these two earnest and energetic men, the race has ever since subsisted here; always, too, in respectability; never, so far as I have known, disgraced by a single unworthy member; but seldom or never, on the other hand, after the first two generations, performing any memorable deed, or so much as putting forward a claim to public notice. Gradually, they have sunk almost out of sight; as old houses, here and there about the streets, get covered half-way to the eaves by the accumulation of new soil. From father to son, for above a hundred years, they followed the sea; a gray-headed shipmaster, in each generation, retiring from the quarter-deck to the homestead, while a boy of fourteen took the hereditary place before the mast, confronting the salt spray and the gale, which had blustered against his sire and grandsire. The boy, also, in due time, passed from the forecastle to the cabin, spent a tempestuous manhood, and returned from his world-wanderings, to grow old, and die, and mingle his dust with the natal earth. This long connection of a family with one spot, as its place of birth and burial, creates a kindred between the human being and the locality, quite independent of any charm in the scenery or moral circumstances that surround him. It is not love, but instinct. The new inhabitant—who came himself from a foreign land, or whose father or grandfather came—has little claim to be called a Salemite; he has no conception of the oyster-like tenacity with which an old settler, over whom his third century is creeping, clings to the spot where his successive generations have been imbedded. It is no matter that the place is joyless for him; that he is weary of the old wooden houses, the mud and dust, the dead level of site and sentiment, the chill east wind, and the chillest of social atmospheres;—all these, and whatever faults besides he may see or imagine, are nothing to the purpose. The spell survives, and just as powerfully as if the natal spot were an earthly paradise. So has it been in my case. I felt it almost as a destiny to make Salem my home; so that the mould of features and cast of character which had all along been familiar here,—ever, as one representative of the race lay down in his grave, another assuming, as it were, his sentry-march along the main street,—might still in my little day be seen and recognized in the old town. Nevertheless, this very sentiment is an evidence that the connection, which has become an unhealthy one, should at last be severed. Human nature will not flourish, any more than a potato, if it be planted and replanted, for too long a series of generations, in the same worn-out soil. My children have had other birthplaces, and, so far as their fortunes may be within my control, shall strike their roots into unaccustomed earth.

Any hereditary rank that they may have possessed or acquired, it has been their policy to conceal. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Planted deep, in the town’s earliest infancy and childhood, by these two earnest and energetic men, the race has ever since subsisted here; always, too, in respectability; never, so far as I have known, disgraced by a single unworthy member; but seldom or never, on the other hand, after the first two generations, performing any memorable deed, or so much as putting forward a claim to public notice. They were solid, substantial people, with a firm grip on the actual, and a disinclination to venture into the airy regions of imagination or speculation. Their energy, which had been a driving force in the founders, seemed to settle into a quiet persistence in their descendants, a capacity for enduring rather than initiating. They were content to walk in the beaten paths, to inherit the fruits of their ancestors’ labor, and to pass on the same quiet legacy to their children. There was a certain sternness, inherited from the Puritan stock, but it was a sternness that had lost its fire, becoming more a matter of habit and decorum than of fervent conviction. They were magistrates, perhaps, or merchants of moderate success, pillars of the community in a passive, unostentatious way. They built no monuments, wrote no books of lasting import, nor did they stir the public mind with any bold or original thought. Their lives flowed on, like a placid river, between banks that were well-defined and never overflowed. This long, unbroken chain of respectable mediocrity stretched from the earliest days of the settlement down to my own time, binding me, in a sense, to the very soil and history of this old town. I felt myself to be the latest link in this chain, inheriting not the fiery spirit of the founders, but the settled, somewhat inert character of those who came after. It was a lineage that offered stability and a sense of belonging, but little inspiration. Standing in the Custom-House, surrounded by the dust and routine of a bygone era, I often reflected on this ancestry. It seemed fitting that I, a descendant of men who had ceased to strive or innovate, should find myself in a place where the past weighed heavily upon the present, and where the most exciting event was the arrival of a ship or the collection of a tariff. My connection to this lineage was a source of quiet pride, perhaps, but also of a certain melancholy, a sense that the vital force of the family had long since been expended. It was into this atmosphere of respectable stagnation, this inherited quietude, that the discovery of the scarlet letter and the story it contained burst like a sudden, unexpected storm, revealing a depth of passion and suffering that had been utterly absent from the placid surface of my own ancestral history.

events.title: Assuming Office: The Narrator's Arrival and His Aged Staff
detailed_summary: The narrator states it was his 'strange, indolent, unjoyous attachment' to Salem that led him to accept a position at the Custom-House after leaving the Old Manse.
He describes feeling a sense of doom or inevitability, as if Salem were his inescapable center, drawing him back despite previous departures.
He recounts ascending the Custom-House steps with the President's commission and being introduced to his corps of subordinates.
He doubts any public functionary ever commanded such a 'patriarchal body of veterans,' noting their aged appearance immediately settled the 'whereabouts of the Oldest Inhabitant.'

The Collector, General Miller, a distinguished soldier, had held his post for over twenty years, shielding the Salem Custom-House and its employees from political vicissitudes due to his own secure position.
General Miller's conservative nature and attachment to familiar faces meant the narrator found mostly aged men, old sea-captains who had 'drifted into this quiet nook' after tempestuous lives.
These men, though prone to age and infirmity (some bedridden for parts of the year), seemed to possess a talisman against death, only occasionally creeping out for 'duty.'

The narrator admits to 'abbreviating the official breath' of some, allowing them to retire, and finds 'pious consolation' in believing this gave them time to repent for the assumed corrupt practices of Custom-House officers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On emerging from the Old Manse, it was chiefly this strange, indolent, unjoyous attachment for my native town, that brought me to fill a place in Uncle Sam’s brick edifice, when I might as well, or better, have gone somewhere else.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Neither the front nor the back entrance of the Custom-House opens on the road to Paradise.

events.text_segment:
On emerging from the Old Manse, it was chiefly this strange, indolent, unjoyous attachment for my native town, that brought me to fill a place in Uncle Sam’s brick edifice, when I might as well, or better, have gone somewhere else. My doom was on me. It was not the first time, nor the second, that I had gone away,—as it seemed, permanently,—but yet returned, like the bad half-penny; or as if Salem were for me the inevitable centre of the universe. So, one fine morning, I ascended the flight of granite steps, with the President’s commission in my pocket, and was introduced to the corps of gentlemen who were to aid me in my weighty responsibility, as chief executive officer of the Custom-House.
I doubt greatly—or, rather, I do not doubt at all—whether any public functionary of the United States, either in the civil or military line, has ever had such a patriarchal body of veterans under his orders as myself. The whereabouts of the Oldest Inhabitant was at once settled, when I looked at them. For upwards of twenty years before this epoch, the independent position of the Collector had kept the Salem Custom-House out of the whirlpool of political vicissitude, which makes the tenure of office generally so fragile. A soldier,—New England’s most distinguished soldier,—he stood firmly on the pedestal of his gallant services; and, himself secure in the wise liberality of the successive administrations through which he had held office, he had been the safety of his subordinates in many an hour of danger and heart-quake. General Miller was radically conservative; a man over whose kindly nature habit had no slight influence; attaching himself strongly to familiar faces, and with difficulty moved to change, even when change might have brought unquestionable improvement. Thus, on taking charge of my department, I found few but aged men. They were ancient sea-captains, for the most part, who, after being tost on every sea, and standing up sturdily against life’s tempestuous blasts, had finally drifted into this quiet nook; where, with little to disturb them, except the periodical terrors of a Presidential election, they one and all acquired a new lease of existence. Though by no means less liable than their fellow-men to age and infirmity, they had evidently some talisman or other that kept death at bay. Two or three of their number, as I was assured, being gouty and rheumatic, or perhaps bedridden, never dreamed of making their appearance at the Custom-House, during a large part of the year; but, after a torpid winter, would creep out into the warm sunshine of May or June, go lazily about what they termed duty, and, at their own leisure and convenience, betake themselves to bed again. I must plead guilty to the charge of abbreviating the official breath of more than one of these venerable servants of the republic. They were allowed, on my representation, to rest from their arduous labors, and soon afterwards—as if their sole principle of life had been zeal for their country’s service, as I verily believe it was—withdrew to a better world. It is a pious consolation to me, that, through my interference, a sufficient space was allowed them for repentance of the evil and corrupt practices into which, as a matter of course, every Custom-House officer must be supposed to fall. Neither the front nor the back entrance of the Custom-House opens on the road to Paradise.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: On emerging from the Old Manse, it was chiefly this strange, indolent, unjoyous attachment for my native town, that brought me to fill a place in Uncle Sam’s brick edifice, when I might as well, or better, have gone somewhere else. My good townspeople, whose approbation I so heartily desired, were kind enough to welcome me; and the President, so far as he knew of my existence, evinced a disposition to sustain me. I went on board the steam-boat, with a man of ten times my claim to public notice, and ten times my estimable qualities, and was infinitely more an object of interest to the crowd, in consequence of already possessing the office which the other was indubitably destined to fill. I had cause to say, without flattery, that a greater man than myself could not have been the occupant of that post. My children, too, were growing up apace; and I thought it high time that they should have an opportunity of observing how a man of genius and sensibility may be debased, and utterly annihilated, by holding a position under Government. With this view, I ascended the steps, and entered the Custom-House. Below stood a row of venerable figures, who, with their hats on, and their hands in their pockets, seemed to have little else to do than to weigh the merits of one another, and to criticise my own. I was introduced to the Collector, General Miller, a gentleman of the old school, and a soldier of the Revolution. He was a man of sterling integrity, and of a kindly heart; but, with the exception of his military services, which were of a high order, his life had been singularly uneventful. He had been Collector of the port for more than twenty years, and had held the office through all the changes of party, and all the vicissitudes of political life. He was a man of few words, and of a grave aspect; but, when he spoke, it was with a voice that was at once deep and melodious. He was a man of a large frame, and of a commanding presence; but, with the exception of his military services, which were of a high order, his life had been singularly uneventful. simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: On emerging from the Old Manse, it was chiefly this strange, indolent, unjoyous attachment for my native town, that brought me to fill a place in Uncle Sam’s brick edifice, when I might as well, or better, have gone somewhere else. My good townspeople, whose approbation I so heartily desired, were kind enough to welcome me; and the President, so far as he knew of my existence, evinced a disposition to sustain me. I went on board the steam-boat, with a man of ten times my claim to public notice, and ten times my estimable qualities, and was infinitely more an object of interest to the crowd, in consequence of already possessing the office which the other was indubitably destined to fill. I had cause to say, without flattery, that a greater man than myself could not have been the occupant of that post. My children, too, were growing up apace; and I thought it high time that they should have an opportunity of observing how a man of genius and sensibility may be debased, and utterly annihilated, by holding a position under Government. With this view, I ascended the steps, and entered the Custom-House. Below stood a row of venerable figures, who, with their hats on, and their hands in their pockets, seemed to have little else to do than to weigh the merits of one another, and to criticise my own. I was introduced to the Collector, General Miller, a gentleman of the old school, and a soldier of the Revolution. He was a man of sterling integrity, and of a kindly heart; but, with the exception of his military services, which were of a high order, his life had been singularly uneventful. events.title: Benevolent Inaction and the Officers' Comfortable Incompetence
detailed_summary: The majority of the narrator's officers were Whigs, but his own non-political stance as a Democrat in principle saved them from dismissal, which an active politician would have likely enforced.
He describes the old officers' palpable fear of him, seeing their weathered cheeks pale and voices tremble, which he found both painful and amusing.
He acknowledges that these men knew they were inefficient and should have been replaced by younger, more politically aligned individuals, a fact he also recognized but lacked the heart to act upon.
To his own discredit and detriment of his official conscience, they continued in their posts, loitering, sleeping, and endlessly repeating old sea-stories and jokes.
The officers soon discovered the new Surveyor was harmless.
They performed their duties with a show of diligence, making a fuss over small matters while sometimes being remarkably obtuse about larger ones, such as smuggled goods.
When such mishaps occurred, they would then exhibit excessive vigilance in securing the delinquent vessel, seemingly earning praise for caution after the fact rather than reprimand for negligence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The greater part of my officers were Whigs.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Instead of a reprimand for their previous negligence, the case seemed rather to require an eulogium on their praiseworthy caution, after the mischief had happened; a grateful recognition of the promptitude of their zeal, the moment that there was no longer any remedy.

events.text_segment:
The greater part of my officers were Whigs. It was well for their venerable brotherhood that the new Surveyor was not a politician, and though a faithful Democrat in principle, neither received nor held his office with any reference to political services. Had it been otherwise,—had an active politician been put into this influential post, to assume the easy task of making head against a Whig Collector, whose infirmities withheld him from the personal administration of his office,—hardly a man of the old corps would have drawn the breath of official life, within a month after the exterminating angel had come up the Custom-House steps. According to the received code in such matters, it would have been nothing short of duty, in a politician, to bring every one of those white heads under the axe of the guillotine. It was plain enough to discern, that the old fellows dreaded some such discourtesy at my hands. It pained, and at the same time amused me, to behold the terrors that attended my advent; to see a furrowed cheek, weather-beaten by half a century of storm, turn ashy pale at the glance of so harmless an individual as myself; to detect, as one or another addressed me, the tremor of a voice, which, in long-past days, had been wont to bellow through a speaking-trumpet, hoarsely enough to frighten Boreas himself to silence. They knew, these excellent old persons, that, by all established rule,—and, as regarded some of them, weighed by their own lack of efficiency for business,—they ought to have given place to younger men, more orthodox in politics, and altogether fitter than themselves to serve our common Uncle. I knew it too, but could never quite find in my heart to act upon the knowledge. Much and deservedly to my own discredit, therefore, and considerably to the detriment of my official conscience, they continued, during my incumbency, to creep about the wharves, and loiter up and down the Custom-House steps. They spent a good deal of time, also, asleep in their accustomed corners, with their chairs tilted back against the wall; awaking, however, once or twice in a forenoon, to bore one another with the several thousandth repetition of old sea-stories, and mouldy jokes, that had grown to be passwords and countersigns among them.
The discovery was soon made, I imagine, that the new Surveyor had no great harm in him. So, with lightsome hearts, and the happy consciousness of being usefully employed,—in their own behalf, at least, if not for our beloved country,—these good old gentlemen went through the various formalities of office. Sagaciously, under their spectacles, did they peep into the holds of vessels! Mighty was their fuss about little matters, and marvellous, sometimes, the obtuseness that allowed greater ones to slip between their fingers! Whenever such a mischance occurred,—when a wagon-load of valuable merchandise had been smuggled ashore, at noonday, perhaps, and directly beneath their unsuspicious noses,—nothing could exceed the vigilance and alacrity with which they proceeded to lock, and double-lock, and secure with tape and sealing-wax, all the avenues of the delinquent vessel. Instead of a reprimand for their previous negligence, the case seemed rather to require an eulogium on their praiseworthy caution, after the mischief had happened; a grateful recognition of the promptitude of their zeal, the moment that there was no longer any remedy.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The greater part of my officers were Whigs. It was my fortune, among the Democratic gentlemen who thronged about President Polk, to be one of the few who had been long enough out of office to acquire the political complexion of at least a presentable Democrat, and not one of those veterans who had worn out all their life-force in vain efforts for the triumph of their party, and were now floundering at the bottom of the tide, on the ebb of fortune, and too old for a new career. But, whether or no this was the case with the majority of my colleagues in office, it was certainly true of the subordinate corps. There were individuals who had held so long in their little niches, and had made themselves so indispensable to the routine of the establishment, that the entire body of officials, with the Collector himself, would have found it difficult to perform their duties without their aid. But, in my portion of the Custom-House, with the Surveyor's office, this was by no means the case. My corps of subordinates consisted of men who had heretofore spent the larger portion of their lives out of office, and who owed their places, in the Custom-House, to the recent Democratic victory. These men were, of course, my political brethren, and were ready to follow my lead, and second my efforts, with that hearty goodwill which is apt to characterize men who are united in a common cause, and who have just achieved a common triumph. But, as I have said, the greater part of my officers were Whigs. These were the incumbents of the Custom-House, who had been appointed by the previous administration, and who, though they had been in office for many years, were still in the prime of life, and were capable of performing their duties with efficiency. But, as I have also said, the greater part of my officers were Whigs. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The greater part of my officers were Whigs. This was natural enough, considering the late change of administration; but it was an odd predicament for a Democratic appointee, such as I was, to be thrown into the midst of them. There they were, old veterans of the Custom-House, who had been appointed by former Whig Presidents, and had somehow weathered the political storms that swept away their comrades. They were a set of venerable fossils, in truth, with all the reverence and some of the rigidity of past ages. Their faces were like parchment, wrinkled and worn, bearing the impress of years spent in a routine that had become their very existence. They had grown into the Custom-House, as barnacles grow into the hull of a ship, fixtures that could not be dislodged without tearing away a part of the structure itself. Their minds, if they had ever been active, had long since settled into a state of placid stagnation. They had no ambition, no curiosity, no interest in anything beyond the narrow confines of their official duties, which, truth to tell, were often more nominal than real. The Custom-House, in those days, was a place where men came to rust, not to work. It was a refuge for the politically superannuated, a comfortable berth where one could draw a salary and doze away the declining years of life. My own position, that of Surveyor, was one of the few that still retained some semblance of active duty, though even that was largely a matter of routine and oversight, requiring little intellectual effort or creative energy. It was a strange environment for a man whose life had been spent in the solitary pursuit of literature, a world of imagination and thought, so utterly different from this realm of ledgers and manifests, of ships arriving and departing, of duties collected and recorded. I felt like a plant transplanted into an alien soil, struggling to take root in a place where the air was thick with the dust of ages and the scent of decay. The building itself seemed to partake of the character of its inhabitants. It was a large, square edifice of brick, with a heavy, unadorned aspect, standing on the edge of the wharf, looking out upon the harbor with a sort of grim indifference. Its interior was dark and gloomy, with long, echoing corridors and spacious, sparsely furnished rooms. The windows were often grimy, admitting only a subdued light that seemed to deepen the shadows within. The furniture was old and worn, bearing the marks of generations of occupants. There was a pervasive smell of dust, of old paper, and of the sea, a combination that spoke of long voyages ended and forgotten, of goods stored and dispersed, of a world that was constantly changing, while this little corner of it remained stubbornly the same. The routine of the place was as unchanging as the tides,

events.title: Growing Fondness and Candid Assessment of the Aged Cohort
detailed_summary: The narrator confesses a 'foolish habit' of contracting kindness for people, usually focusing on their better traits.
As most of the old Custom-House officers possessed good qualities, and his paternal, protective role fostered friendly sentiments, he soon grew to like them all.

He found it pleasant to hear them chatting in the summer, their old witticisms 'thawed out' by the warmth, comparing their aged jollity to children's mirth – a surface gleam, like the 'phosphorescent glow of decaying wood' rather than real sunshine.
He clarifies that not all his colleagues were in their dotage; some were able men in their prime, unfortunately cast into a sluggish life.
However, he characterizes the majority as 'wearisome old souls' who had retained only the 'husks' of their life experiences, not the 'golden grain of practical wisdom.'
They spoke with more enthusiasm about daily meals than about significant past events like shipwrecks or world wonders they had witnessed in their youth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Unless people are more than commonly disagreeable, it is my foolish habit to contract a kindness for them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They spoke with far more interest and unction of their morning’s breakfast, or yesterday’s, to-day’s, or to-morrow’s dinner, than of the shipwreck of forty or fifty years ago, and all the world’s wonders which they had witnessed with their youthful eyes.

events.text_segment:
Unless people are more than commonly disagreeable, it is my foolish habit to contract a kindness for them. The better part of my companion’s character, if it have a better part, is that which usually comes uppermost in my regard, and forms the type whereby I recognize the man. As most of these old Custom-House officers had good traits, and as my position in reference to them, being paternal and protective, was favorable to the growth of friendly sentiments, I soon grew to like them all. It was pleasant, in the summer forenoons,—when the fervent heat, that almost liquefied the rest of the human family, merely communicated a genial warmth to their half-torpid systems,—it was pleasant to hear them chatting in the back entry, a row of them all tipped against the wall, as usual; while the frozen witticisms of past generations were thawed out, and came bubbling with laughter from their lips. Externally, the jollity of aged men has much in common with the mirth of children; the intellect, any more than a deep sense of humor, has little to do with the matter; it is, with both, a gleam that plays upon the surface, and imparts a sunny and cheery aspect alike to the green branch, and gray, mouldering trunk. In one case, however, it is real sunshine; in the other, it more resembles the phosphorescent glow of decaying wood.
It would be sad injustice, the reader must understand, to represent all my excellent old friends as in their dotage. In the first place, my coadjutors were not invariably old; there were men among them in their strength and prime, of marked ability and energy, and altogether superior to the sluggish and dependent mode of life on which their evil stars had cast them. Then, moreover, the white locks of age were sometimes found to be the thatch of an intellectual tenement in good repair. But, as respects the majority of my corps of veterans, there will be no wrong done, if I characterize them generally as a set of wearisome old souls, who had gathered nothing worth preservation from their varied experience of life. They seemed to have flung away all the golden grain of practical wisdom, which they had enjoyed so many opportunities of harvesting, and most carefully to have stored their memories with the husks. They spoke with far more interest and unction of their morning’s breakfast, or yesterday’s, to-day’s, or to-morrow’s dinner, than of the shipwreck of forty or fifty years ago, and all the world’s wonders which they had witnessed with their youthful eyes.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Unless people are more than commonly disagreeable, it is my foolish habit to contract a kindness for them. The disagreeable qualities of my Custom-House associates were neither so great nor so many as to interrupt the gentle current of kindly feeling. They were good old gentlemen, mild, quiet, peaceable, sociable, having no great harm in them, though apt to be peevish, querulous, grumbling, and otherwise disagreeable, at times; but, on the whole, elderly men, easy to deal with, and who cost one nothing, except in the way of sympathy and fellow-feeling. These latter commodities, it is true, they required in very large quantities, and I dole them out rather liberally, having a great deal of sympathy to spare. But, in truth, this was the chief trouble in the way of living pleasantly with them. They were sluggish wretches, who had stagnated into a life of carelessness and indolence, and had lost all motive for exertion, except, perhaps, that of keeping themselves tolerably warm when they got cool, or of soothing their ill-humor by a little sugar in their tea. Their talk, especially on rainy days, was apt to run into the infinite series of personal complaints, which might have been borne patiently enough, but for the fact that they were always in precisely the same tone and pitch, and without the slightest variation of idea. I remember one poor fellow—a very ancient personage, employed in weighing coal—who had spent a lifetime in that business, and had never, I believe, been twenty miles from his native town; yet he would talk of London, and Liverpool, and the Mediterranean, and the East Indies, and other countries of which he knew nothing, as if he had been a seasoned traveller. He was a man of few words, but those few were always about himself, and his own personal concerns. He was a bachelor, and had no friends, and no relations, and no acquaintances, and no interests, and no ideas, and no feelings, and no sympathies, and no anything. He was a mere husk of a man, with nothing in him but a little dry dust. I have seen him sit for hours together, with his head sunk upon his breast, and his eyes closed, in a state of torpid indifference, which nothing could rouse him from, except the call to dinner. He was a man of such perfect equanimity, that he would have heard the trump of doom without stirring a muscle. He was a man of such perfect indifference, that he would have seen the world on fire without remarking it. He was a man of such perfect apathy, that he would have felt the pangs of death without a groan. He was a man of such perfect insensibility, that he would have been cut to pieces without a murmur. simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: Unless people are more than commonly disagreeable, it is my foolish habit to contract a kindness for them. The disagreeable qualities of my Custom-House associates were neither so great nor so many as to interrupt the gentle current of kindly feeling. They were good old gentlemen, mild, quiet, peaceable, sociable, having no great harm in them, though apt to be peevish, querulous, grumbling, and otherwise disagreeable, at times; but, on the whole, elderly men, easy to deal with, and who cost one nothing, except in the way of sympathy and fellow-feeling. These latter commodities, it is true, they required in very large quantities, and I dole them out rather liberally, having a great deal of sympathy to spare. But, in truth, this was the chief trouble in the way of living pleasantly with them. They were sluggish wretches, who had stagnated into a life of carelessness and indolence, and had lost all motive for exertion, except, perhaps, that of keeping themselves tolerably warm when they got cool, or of soothing their ill-humor by a little sugar in their tea. Their talk, especially on rainy days, was apt to run into the infinite series of personal complaints, which might have been borne patiently enough, but for the fact that they were always in precisely the same tone and pitch, and without the slightest variation of idea. I remember one poor fellow—a very ancient personage, employed in weighing coal—who had spent a lifetime in that business, and had never, I believe, been twenty miles from his native town; yet he would talk of London, and Liverpool, and the Mediterranean, and the East Indies, and other countries of which he knew nothing, as if he had been a seasoned traveller. He was a man of few words, but those few were always about himself, and his own personal concerns. He was a bachelor, and had no friends, and no relations, and no acquaintances, and no interests, and no ideas, and no feelings, and no sympathies, and no anything. He was a mere husk of a man, with nothing in him but a little dry dust. I have seen him sit for hours together, with his head sunk upon his breast, and his eyes closed, in a state of torpid indifference, which nothing could rouse him from, except the call to dinner. He was a man of such perfect equanimity, that he would have heard the trump of doom without stirring a muscle. He was a man of such perfect indifference, that he would have seen the world on fire without remarking it. events.title: The Ageless Inspector: A Study in Animal Vitality and Epicureanism
detailed_summary: The narrator introduces the 'father of the Custom-House,' a permanent Inspector, around eighty years old but remarkably vital and well-preserved, likened to 'winter-green.'
This Inspector is described as physically robust, with a florid cheek, compact figure, brisk step, and hearty voice and laugh, seemingly untouched by age and infirmity.

His enduring health is attributed to a rare perfection of his 'animal nature,' moderate intellect, and a minimal presence of moral or spiritual qualities – just enough to keep him from walking on all-fours.
He possessed no deep thought, feeling, or troublesome sensibilities, only commonplace instincts and a cheerful temper stemming from physical well-being.
Despite having outlived three wives and most of his twenty children, he bore these sorrows lightly, quickly returning to a childlike readiness for sport.

The narrator studied this 'patriarchal personage' with curiosity, concluding he lacked soul, heart, and mind, being a creature of instinct, yet so well-assembled that there was no painful sense of deficiency.

The Inspector's gourmandism was a notable trait; he relished talking about food, and his recollections of past banquets seemed to bring their savors to life, with flavors lingering on his palate for decades.
The chief tragic event of his life was a culinary mishap with an incredibly tough goose from many years ago.
The narrator considers this Inspector perfectly suited to be a Custom-House officer, as he was incapable of suffering moral detriment from the lifestyle and would always maintain a good appetite.
